questions.text: Which of the following is an immune-privileged site?
questions.explanation:
Brain

Blood-brain barrier

Eyes

Blood-ocular barrier

Testes

Blood-testicular barrier

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a six-year-old male presents with a history of frequent respiratory and skin infections, eczema flare-ups, and macrothrombocytopenia. Given these symptoms, which genetic evaluation method would be the most effective for confirming the suspected diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: B cell tyrosine kinase activity detection

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with recurrent skin abscesses and pneumonia. He also has a history of skeletal abnormalities, including scoliosis and delayed shedding of primary teeth. His lab work shows elevated serum IgE levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient presents with autoimmune hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and neutropenia. Based on the flow cytometry findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Quadrant 1 (green)

Negative for antigen A, positive for antigen B

Quadrant 2 (purple)

Negative for both antigens

Quadrant 3 (yellow)

Positive for both antigens

Quadrant 4 (red)

Positive for antigen A, negative for antigen B

questions.text: Match the following. i) X-linked Agammaglobulinemia a) WAS ii) Job syndrome b) LYST iii) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome c) STAT3 iv) Ataxia Telangiectasia d) BTK v) Chediak-Higashi syndrome e) ATM
questions.correct_answer: D. i-d, ii-c, iii-a, iv-e, v-b
questions.explanation:
X-linked (Bruton) Agammaglobulinemia

BTK

Job syndrome (Hyper IgE syndrome)

STAT3

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

WAS

Ataxia Telangiectasia

ATM

Chediak-Higashi syndrome

LYST

Defects in Leukocyte Function

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1

Defective leukocyte adhesion because of mutations in the β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 2

Defective leukocyte adhesion because of mutations in fucosyl transferase required for the synthesis of sialylated oligosaccharide (receptor for selectins)

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 3

LAD-III is caused by mutations in the FERMT3 gene, which encodes kindlin-3, a cytoskeletal protein. These mutations disrupt the signalling of integrins on platelets and leukocytes, which impairs cellular adhesion

Chédiak-Higashi syndrome

Autosomal recessive, decreased leukocyte functions because of mutations affecting protein (LYST) involved in lysosomal membrane traffic. Defective phagolysosome formation.

Chronic granulomatous disease

Decreased oxidative burst

Myeloperoxidase deficiency

Decreased microbial killing because of defective MPO-H2O2 system

Defects in the Complement System

C2, C4 deficiency

Defective classical pathway activation results in reduced resistance to infection and reduced clearance of immune complexes

C3 deficiency

Defects in all complement functions

Deficiency of complement regulatory proteins

Excessive complement activation; clinical syndromes include angioedema (C1 inhibitor deficiency), paroxysmal hemoglobinuria (CD55/59 deficiency), others

SCID
  • X-linked (most common): mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors
  • Autosomal recessive: ADA enzyme deficiency

X-Linked Agammaglobulinemia (Bruton Agammaglobulinemia)
  • BTK gene mutation
  • X-linked recessive

DiGeorge Syndrome (Thymic Hypoplasia)
  • CATCH22 (mnemonic) - Cardiac defects, Abnormal facies, Thymic hypoplasia, Cleft palate, Hypocalcemia (tetany) resulting from lack of parathyroids, 22q11 microdeletion

Hyper IgM syndrome
  • Defective CD40L on helper T cells → class switching defect
  • X-linked recessive

Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Cause unknown
  • Defects in B and T cells
  • Defective B cell: BAFF gene defect
  • Defective T cell: ICOS gene defect
  • Diagnosed in late childhood or adulthood

Isolated IgA Deficiency
  • Caused by impaired differentiation of naïve B lymphocytes to IgA-producing plasma cells

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome
  • Mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP)

Ataxia Telangiectasia
  • Autosomal recessive
  • ATM gene mutation located on chromosome 11

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with a history of recurrent respiratory infections, chronic diarrhoea, and autoimmune manifestations. Laboratory investigations reveal low levels of serum immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, and IgM). Which of the following immunodeficiency disorders is most likely associated with these clinical findings?

An 8-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with a history of persistent, severe respiratory infections since birth. Physical examination reveals failure to thrive and absent tonsils and lymph nodes. The Child is diagnosed with adenosine deaminase deficiency; what is the most appropriate diagnosis?

In a pediatric clinic, a six-year-old male presents with a history of frequent respiratory and skin infections, eczema flare-ups, and macrothrombocytopenia. Given these symptoms, which genetic evaluation method would be the most effective for confirming the suspected diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: B cell tyrosine kinase activity detection

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of dermatomyositis?

A patient presented with oliguria for the last three days. She is a known case of diabetic nephropathy and underwent an allogeneic renal transplant four years ago. The physician suspects a possibility of graft rejection. Which of the following is not true regarding the suspected condition in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Manifests as interstitial fibrosis and narrowing of graft blood vessels

options.label: C
options.text: HPE shows duplication of the basement membrane

options.label: D
options.text: Its morphologic correlate in the lung is bronchiolitis obliterans

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with a widespread rash, severe diarrhoea, and jaundice. He underwent bonemarrow transplantation for acute myeloid leukaemia and received cells from a matched, unrelated donor. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated for proximal muscle weakness. Which of the following is consistent with a diagnosis of polymyositis?

options.label: A
options.text: CD4+ T cell infiltration in affected tissue

questions.text: What is the minimum HLA matching that should be achieved to proceed with the transplant in the pediatric population?
questions.explanation:
If these HLA Antigens and Alleles Match

Then, the donor is considered to be this type of match:

A, B and DRB1

6/6

A, B, C, and DRB1

8/8

A, B, C, DRB1 and DQB1

10/10

A, B, C, DRB1, DQB1 and DPB1

12/12

questions.text: A 20-year-old female complains of recurrent episodes of her fingers turning symmetrically white, which are associated with pain and a tingling sensation. This is worse when exposed to cold water and is relieved when she dips her fingers in warm water. The autoimmune panel is negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Primary Raynaud's phenomenon

Secondary Raynaud's phenomenon

Associated diseases

No

Yes

Age at onset

Younger (<30)

Older (>30)

Nail fold capillaries

Normal

Large tortuous

Autoantibodies

Negative to low

Frequent

Endothelial cell activation

Yes

Yes

Endothelial damage

No

Frequent

Occlusions

No

Yes

Digital gangrene

Rare (superficial)

Common

α2 adrenergic activity

High

High

Calcitonin gene-related peptide

Low

Low

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of innate immunity?

options.label: B
options.text: Made of epithelial barriers, phagocytes, innate lymphoid cells (ILCs) and NK cells

options.label: D
options.text: Has a lag phase between exposure and response

questions.correct_answer: D. Has a lag phase between exposure and response
questions.explanation:
Innate/native immunity

Acquired/adaptive immunity

Present since birth (Option A)

Occurs after exposure to the pathogen

Quick, non-specific response (Option C)

Slower, specific response to a pathogen

No immunological memory

Has immunological memory

Examples include :

  • Epithelial barriers like skin, GIT. (Option B)
  • Plasma proteins like C-reactive protein.
  • Neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells, complement.

Cells are of 2 types :

  • B lymphocytes: Provides humoral immunity and produces antibodies
  • 2. T lymphocytes: Involved in cell-mediated immunity and help with immunity against intracellular microbes

questions.text: Match the following processes in immune tolerance with their associated regulators. Process Regulators 1. Negative selection a. CD-28 2. Anergy b. FOXP3 3. Deletion by apoptosis c. AIRE 4. Suppression by regulatory T cells d. CD95

A 60-year-old man with poorly controlled hypertension and diabetes presents with fatigue, shortness of breath, ankle swelling, hepatomegaly, and bilateral lower extremity oedema. Labs show proteinuria and elevated serum creatinine. Which staining technique is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Stains/technique

Appearance

Congo red
  • Most widely used and specific.
  • Light microscopy: Salmon pink/red stains.
  • Polarising microscopy: Apple-green birefringence.

H & E
  • Eosin & hematoxylin staining on light microscopy.
  • Amorphous, eosinophilic, extracellular substance.

Thioflavin T
  • Fluorescent stain.
  • Yellow colour under UV light.

Electron microscopy
  • Non-branching fibrils of indefinite length.
  • Diameter: 7.5-10 nm.

X-ray crystallography & infrared spectroscopy
  • Cross-β-pleated sheet conformation.

Methyl violet

Crystal violet

PAS
  • Amyloid positive.

questions.text: Match the following. Condition Amyloid protein 1 Chronic inflammation i ATTR 2 Alzheimer’s disease ii AA 3 Familial amyloid polyneuropathy iii AIAPP 4 Diabetes mellitus iv Aβ
questions.explanation:
Disease

Amyloid

Multiple myeloma and other monoclonal plasma cell disorders

AL

Chronic inflammation

AA

Alzheimer’s disease

Aβ

Familial amyloid polyneuropathy

ATTR (mutated form of transthyretin)

Diabetes mellitus

AIAPP

Hemodialysis associated amyloidosis

Aβ2m

Familial Meditterean Fever

AA

Senile systemic amyloidosis

ATTR (Increased quantity of TTR, no mutation is seen)

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid

Acal

Isolated atrial amyloidosis

AANF

questions.text: Identify the false statements regarding the amyloid. 1) It is a proteoglycan. 2) It is a misfolded protein seen intracellularly. 3) They show cross-β-pleated sheet conformation in light microscopy. 4) 95% of amyloid consists of fibril proteins. 5) It appears as an amorphous, basophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.
Which of the following sequences correctly describes the phases of pathogenesis in Type III hypersensitivity?

options.label: A
options.text: Formation of immune complexes → Inflammation and tissue injury → Deposition in blood vessels.

options.label: B
options.text: Deposition of immune complexes → Formation of antibodies → Tissue injury and inflammation.

options.label: C
options.text: Formation of immune complexes → Deposition in tissues → Inflammation and tissue injury.

options.label: D
options.text: Antibody production → Immune complex formation → Activation of cytotoxic T cells.

questions.correct_answer: C. Formation of immune complexes → Deposition in tissues → Inflammation and tissue injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is typically associated with localized immune-complex mediated hypersensitivity?
questions.explanation:
Systemic type III hypersensitivity

Localised type III hypersensitivity

Involves the widespread formation of immune complexes in circulation and can deposit in various tissues and organs throughout the body, including the kidneys (leading to glomerulonephritis), joints, skin, blood vessels, and other sites. (e.g., in chronic infections or autoimmune diseases).

Immune complexes are deposited at specific sites of antigen exposure, such as the skin (as in the Arthus reaction) or joint spaces, leading to local inflammation (localized swelling, redness, pain) and tissue damage.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding pernicious anaemia is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Natural Killer (NK) cells participate in Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity.

options.label: B
options.text: Opsonisation involves IgG antibodies coating cells, enhancing phagocytosis via Fc receptors.

options.label: C
options.text: When antibodies deposit in intracellular tissues, the injury is due to inflammation and not phagocytosis or cell lysis.

options.label: D
options.text: Myasthenia gravis is an example of antibody-mediated cell surface receptor dysfunction.

questions.correct_answer: C. When antibodies deposit in intracellular tissues, the injury is due to inflammation and not phagocytosis or cell lysis.
questions.explanation:
Mechanisms of Type II hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Opsonisation and Phagocytosis
(Option B)

IgG antibodies coat cells, helping phagocytes recognise circulating antigen-opsonin complexes through Fc receptors or complement activation, leading to phagocytosis.

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia

  • Immune thrombocytopenic purpura

  • Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn.

Complement activation

and inflammation
(Option C)

Antibody deposition in extracellular tissues triggers inflammation, not phagocytosis or cell lysis. The deposited antibodies activate the complement system, leading to the attraction of neutrophils and monocytes via their Fc receptors. Activated leukocytes release enzymes, resulting in tissue damage.

  • Goodpasture syndrome

  • Acute rheumatic fever

Antibody-dependent

cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)
(Option A)

Natural killer cells bind to antibody-antigen complexes, inducing apoptotic cell death.

  • Pernicious anemia

  • Insulin resistant diabetes

Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction (non-cytotoxic)
(Option D)

Antibodies physically impair or dysregulate cellular function by binding to cell surface receptors. This includes both activation (e.g., thyroid hormone receptor in Graves disease) and inhibition (e.g., acetylcholine receptor in Myasthenia gravis).

  • Graves disease

  • Myasthenia gravis

IgG antibodies coat cells, helping phagocytes recognise circulating antigen-opsonin complexes through Fc receptors or complement activation, leading to phagocytosis.

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia

  • Immune thrombocytopenic purpura

  • Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn.

(Option C)

Antibody deposition in extracellular tissues triggers inflammation, not phagocytosis or cell lysis. The deposited antibodies activate the complement system, leading to the attraction of neutrophils and monocytes via their Fc receptors.   • Goodpasture syndrome

cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)
(Option A)

  • Pernicious anemia

Antibodies physically impair or dysregulate cellular function by binding to cell surface receptors. This includes both activation (e.g., thyroid hormone receptor in Graves disease) and inhibition (e.g., acetylcholine receptor in Myasthenia gravis).

  • Graves disease

  • Myasthenia gravis

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not an example of a Type II hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.explanation:
Mnemonic: My Blood Group Is Rh Positive

My

Myasthenia Gravis

Blood

Blood transfusion reaction

Group

Good pasture syndrome,

Graves disease

Is

Immune hemolytic anaemia,

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura

R

Rh incompatibility,

Rheumatic fever

H

Hyperacute transplant rejection

Positive

Pemphigus (Bullous),

Pernicious Anemia

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction?
Which of the following cytokines acts on B cells to stimulate class switching to IgE and promotes the development of additional Th2 cells in type I hypersensitivity reactions?
questions.explanation:
Interleukins

Role

IL-4
  • Key cytokine in driving the allergic response
  • Enhances Ig E-mediated reaction
  • Stimulates B cells to undergo class switching to IgE and promotes the expansion of Th2 cells

IL-5 (Option B)

Development and activation of eosinophils→ Recruited to the site of allergen exposure→ Release inflammatory mediators and enzymes→ Tissue damage and inflammation

IL-13 (Option C)
  • Amplifies IgE production
  • Acts on epithelial cells to stimulate mucus secretion

IL-10 (Option D)
  • Anti-inflammatory cytokine
  • Inhibits cytokine production by Th1 cells and macrophages.

questions.text: A newborn delivered by a mother who received no prenatal care is being evaluated. On examination, the baby has severe oedema, icterus, and organomegaly and is in respiratory distress. What immunoglobulin class was responsible for this child’s presentation?
Which of the following HLA gene regions encodes Class II MHC molecules?
questions.explanation:
Gene region

Encoded products

Class I
  • HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Class II
  • HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Class III
  • Tumor necrosis factor (TNF), complement and heat shock proteins

questions.explanation:
Cells

Markers

Natural killer cell

CD 16, 56, 94

CD 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 28, 40L.

CD 10, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 40, 79

Monocyte
